member.name: T:FluentFTP.Extensions.ChecksumExtension
member.summary: Retrieve checksum of file on the server

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.ChecksumExtension.GetChecksum(FluentFTP.FtpClient,System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves a checksum of the given file using a checksumming method that the server supports, if any. The algorithm used goes in this order: 1. HASH command; server preferred algorithm. See FtpClient.SetHashAlgorithm() 2. MD5 / XMD5 commands 3. XSHA1 command 4. XSHA256 command 5. XSHA512 command 6. XCRC command
member.param: Full or relative path of the file to checksum
member.returns: FtpHash object containing the value and algorithm. Use the IsValid property to determine if this command was successfull. FtpCommandException's can be thrown from the underlying calls.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.ChecksumExtension.BeginGetChecksum(FluentFTP.FtpClient,System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Asynchronusly retrieve a checksum of the specified file. This feature is non-standard.
member.param: Full or relative path to remote file

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.ChecksumExtension.EndGetChecksum(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Ends an asynchronous call to BeginGetChecksum()
member.returns: FtpHash object containing the value and algorithm. Use the IsValid property to determine if this command was successfull. FtpCommandException's can be thrown from the underlying calls.

member.name: T:FluentFTP.Extensions.MD5
member.summary: Implementation of the non-standard MD5 command

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.MD5.GetMD5(FluentFTP.FtpClient,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the MD5 hash of the specified file using MD5. This is a non-standard extension to the protocol and may or may not work. A FtpCommandException will be thrown if the command fails.
member.param: Full or relative path to remote file
member.returns: Server response, presumably the MD5 hash.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.MD5.BeginGetMD5(FluentFTP.FtpClient,System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Asynchronusly retrieve a MD5 hash. The MD5 command is non-standard and not guaranteed to work.
member.param: Full or relative path to remote file

member.name: M:FluentFTP.Extensions.MD5.EndGetMD5(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Ends an asynchronous call to BeginGetMD5()
member.returns: The MD5 hash of the specified file.

member.name: T:FluentFTP.FtpClient
member.summary:
FTP Control Connection. Speaks the FTP protocol with the server and provides facilities for performing basic transactions.
Debugging problems with FTP transactions is much easier to do when you can see exactly what is sent to the server and the reply FluentFTP gets in return. Please review the Debug example below for information on how to add TraceListeners for capturing the convorsation between FluentFTP and the server.
member.example: The following example illustrates how to assist in debugging FluentFTP by getting a transaction log from the server.
The following example demonstrates adding a custom file listing parser in the event that you encounter a list format not already supported.
The following example demonstrates how to validate a SSL certificate when using SSL/TLS.
The following example demonsrates how to download a file.
The following example demonstrates how to download a file using a URI object.
The following example demonstrates how to upload a file.
The following example demonstrates how to upload a file using a URI object.
The following example demonstrates how to append to a file.
The following example demonstrates how to append to a file using a URI object.
The following example demonstrates how to get a file listing from the server.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.GetObjectInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Returns information about a file system object. You should check the Capabilities flags for the FtpCapability.MLSD flag before calling this method. Failing to do so will result in an InvalidOperationException being thrown when the server does not support machine listings. Returns null if the server response can't be parsed or the server returns a failure completion code. The error for a failure is logged with FtpTrace. No exception is thrown on error because that would negate the usefullness of this method for checking for the existence of an object.
member.param: The path of the object to retrieve information about

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.BeginGetObjectInfo(System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns information about a file system object. You should check the Capabilities flags for the FtpCapability.MLSD flag before calling this method. Failing to do so will result in an InvalidOperationException being thrown when the server does not support machine listings. Returns null if the server response can't be parsed or the server returns a failure completion code. The error for a failure is logged with FtpTrace. No exception is thrown on error because that would negate the usefullness of this method for checking for the existence of an object.
member.param: Path of the item to retrieve information about

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.EndGetObjectInfo(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Ends a call to BeginGetObjectInfo
member.returns: FtpListItem if the command succeeded, null if there was a problem.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.GetListing
member.summary: Gets a file listing from the server. Each FtpListItem object returned contains information about the file that was able to be retrieved. If a DateTime property is equal to DateTime.MinValue then it means the date in question was not able to be retrieved. If the Size property is equal to 0 then it means the size of the object could also not be retrieved.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DirectoryExists(System.String)
member.summary: Tests if the specified directory exists on the server. This method works by trying to change the working directory to the path specified. If it succeeds, the directory is changed back to the old working directory and true is returned. False is returned otherwise and since the CWD failed it is assumed the working directory is still the same.
member.returns: True if it exists, false otherwise.

member.returns: The FtpHashType flag or FtpHashType.NONE if there was a problem.

member.summary: Asynchronously get the hash algorithm being used by the HASH command.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.SetHashAlgorithm(FluentFTP.FtpHashAlgorithm)
member.summary: Tells the server which hash algorith to use for the HASH command. If you specifiy an algorithm not listed in FtpClient.HashTypes a NotImplemented() exectpion will be thrown so be sure to query that list of Flags before selecting a hash algorithm. Support for the HASH command is experimental. Please see the following link for more details: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.BeginSetHashAlgorithm(FluentFTP.FtpHashAlgorithm,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Asynchronously sets the hash algorithm type to be used with the HASH command.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.EndSetHashAlgorithm(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Ends an asynchronous call to BeginSetHashAlgorithm

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.GetHash(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the hash of an object on the server using the currently selected hash algorithm. Supported algorithms, if any, are available in the HashAlgorithms property. You should confirm that it's not equal to FtpHashAlgorithm.NONE before calling this method otherwise the server trigger a FtpCommandException() due to a lack of support for the HASH command. You can set the algorithm using the SetHashAlgorithm() method and you can query the server for the current hash algorithm using the GetHashAlgorithm() method.
This feature is experimental and based on the following draft: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02
member.param: Full or relative path of the object to compute the hash for.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.BeginGetHash(System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Asynchronously retrieves the hash for the specified file
member.param: The file you want the server to compute the hash for

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.EndGetHash(System.IAsyncResult)
member.summary: Ends an asynchronous call to BeginGetHash

member.name: M:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DisableUTF8
member.summary: Disables UTF8 support and changes the Encoding property back to ASCII. If the server returns an error when trying to turn UTF8 off a FtpCommandException will be thrown.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if this object has already been disposed.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.InternetProtocolVersions
member.summary: Flags specifying which versions of the internet protocol to support when making a connection. All addresses returned during name resolution are tried until a successful connection is made. You can fine tune which versions of the internet protocol to use by adding or removing flags here. I.e., setting this property to FtpIpVersion.IPv4 will cause the connection process to ignore IPv6 addresses. The default value is ANY version.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.SocketPollInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds that must pass since the last socket activity before calling Poll() on the socket to test for connectivity. Setting this interval too low will have a negative impact on perfomance. Setting this interval to 0 disables Poll()'ing all together. The default value is 15 seconds.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.StaleDataCheck
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a test should be performed to see if there is stale (unrequested data) sitting on the socket. In some cases the control connection may time out but before the server closes the connection it might send a 4xx response that was unexpected and can cause synchronization errors with transactions. To avoid this problem the Execute() method checks to see if there is any data available on the socket before executing a command. On Azure hosting platforms this check can cause an exception to be thrown. In order to work around the exception you can set this property to false which will skip the test entirely however doing so eliminates the best effort attempt of detecting such scenarios. See this thread for more details about the Azure problem: https://netftp.codeplex.com/discussions/535879

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.IsConnected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the connection is alive

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.EnableThreadSafeDataConnections
member.summary: When this value is set to true (default) the control connection is cloned and a new connection the server is established for the data channel operation. This is a thread safe approach to make asynchronous operations on a single control connection transparent to the developer.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.Encoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the text encoding being used when talking with the server. The default value is Encoding.ASCII however upon connection, the client checks for UTF8 support and if it's there this property is switched over to Encoding.UTF8. Manually setting this value overrides automatic detection based on the FEAT list; if you change this value it's always used regardless of what the server advertises, if anything.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.Host
member.summary: The server to connect to

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.Port
member.summary: The port to connect to. If this value is set to 0 (Default) the port used will be determined by the type of SSL used or if no SSL is to be used it will automatically connect to port 21.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.Credentials
member.summary: Credentials used for authentication

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.MaximumDereferenceCount
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that controls the maximum depth of recursion that DereferenceLink() will follow symbolic links before giving up. You can also specify the value to be used as one of the overloaded parameters to the DereferenceLink() method. The default value is 20. Specifying -1 here means inifinitly try to resolve a link. This is not recommended for obvious reasons (stack overflow).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.ClientCertificates
member.summary: Client certificates to be used in SSL authentication process

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DataConnectionType
member.summary: Data connection type, default is AutoPassive which tries a connection with EPSV first and if it fails then tries PASV before giving up. If you know exactly which kind of connection you need you can slightly increase performance by defining a speicific type of passive or active data connection here.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.UngracefullDisconnection
member.summary: Disconnect from the server without sending QUIT. This helps work around IOExceptions caused by buggy connection resets when closing the control connection.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.ConnectTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds to wait for a connection attempt to succeed before giving up. Default is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.ReadTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time wait in miliseconds for data to be read from the underlying stream. The default value is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DataConnectionConnectTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds for a data connection to be established before giving up. Default is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DataConnectionReadTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds the data channel should wait for the server to send data. Default value is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.SocketKeepAlive
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if SocketOption.KeepAlive should be set on the underlying stream's socket. If the connection is alive, the option is adjusted in real-time. The value is stored and the KeepAlive option is set accordingly upon any new connections. The value set here is also applied to all future data streams. It has no affect on cloned control connections or data connections already in progress. The default value is false.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.Capabilities
member.summary: Gets the server capabilties represented by flags

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.HashAlgorithms
member.summary: Get the hash types supported by the server, if any. This is a recent extension to the protocol that is not fully standardized and is not guarateed to work. See here for more details: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.EncryptionMode
member.summary: Type of SSL to use, or none. Default is none. Explicit is TLS, Implicit is SSL.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.IFtpClient.DataConnectionEncryption
member.summary: Indicates if data channel transfers should be encrypted. Only valid if EncryptionMode property is not equal to FtpSslMode.None.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpClient.GetObjectInfo(System.String)
member.summary: Returns information about a file system object. You should check the Capabilities flags for the FtpCapability.MLSD flag before calling this method. Failing to do so will result in an InvalidOperationException being thrown when the server does not support machine listings. Returns null if the server response can't be parsed or the server returns a failure completion code. The error for a failure is logged with FtpTrace. No exception is thrown on error because that would negate the usefullness of this method for checking for the existence of an object.
member.param: The path of the object to retrieve information about

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpClient.BeginGetObjectInfo(System.String,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Returns information about a file system object. You should check the Capabilities flags for the FtpCapability.MLSD flag before calling this method. Failing to do so will result in an InvalidOperationException being thrown when the server does not support machine listings. Returns null if the server response can't be parsed or the server returns a failure completion code. The error for a failure is logged with FtpTrace. No exception is thrown on error because that would negate the usefullness of this method for checking for the existence of an object.
member.param: Path of the item to retrieve information about

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpClient.DirectoryExists(System.String)
member.summary: Tests if the specified directory exists on the server. This method works by trying to change the working directory to the path specified. If it succeeds, the directory is changed back to the old working directory and true is returned. False is returned otherwise and since the CWD failed it is assumed the working directory is still the same.
member.returns: True if it exists, false otherwise.

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpClient.SetHashAlgorithm(FluentFTP.FtpHashAlgorithm)
member.summary: Tells the server which hash algorith to use for the HASH command. If you specifiy an algorithm not listed in FtpClient.HashTypes a NotImplemented() exectpion will be thrown so be sure to query that list of Flags before selecting a hash algorithm. Support for the HASH command is experimental. Please see the following link for more details: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpClient.GetHash(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the hash of an object on the server using the currently selected hash algorithm. Supported algorithms, if any, are available in the HashAlgorithms property. You should confirm that it's not equal to FtpHashAlgorithm.NONE before calling this method otherwise the server trigger a FtpCommandException() due to a lack of support for the HASH command. You can set the algorithm using the SetHashAlgorithm() method and you can query the server for the current hash algorithm using the GetHashAlgorithm() method.
This feature is experimental and based on the following draft: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02
member.param: Full or relative path of the object to compute the hash for.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.IsDisposed
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if this object has already been disposed.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.BaseStream
member.summary: Gets the base stream for talking to the server via the control connection.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.InternetProtocolVersions
member.summary: Flags specifying which versions of the internet protocol to support when making a connection. All addresses returned during name resolution are tried until a successful connection is made. You can fine tune which versions of the internet protocol to use by adding or removing flags here. I.e., setting this property to FtpIpVersion.IPv4 will cause the connection process to ignore IPv6 addresses. The default value is ANY version.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.SocketPollInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds that must pass since the last socket activity before calling Poll() on the socket to test for connectivity. Setting this interval too low will have a negative impact on perfomance. Setting this interval to 0 disables Poll()'ing all together. The default value is 15 seconds.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.StaleDataCheck
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a test should be performed to see if there is stale (unrequested data) sitting on the socket. In some cases the control connection may time out but before the server closes the connection it might send a 4xx response that was unexpected and can cause synchronization errors with transactions. To avoid this problem the Execute() method checks to see if there is any data available on the socket before executing a command. On Azure hosting platforms this check can cause an exception to be thrown. In order to work around the exception you can set this property to false which will skip the test entirely however doing so eliminates the best effort attempt of detecting such scenarios. See this thread for more details about the Azure problem: https://netftp.codeplex.com/discussions/535879

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.IsConnected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if the connection is alive

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.EnableThreadSafeDataConnections
member.summary: When this value is set to true (default) the control connection is cloned and a new connection the server is established for the data channel operation. This is a thread safe approach to make asynchronous operations on a single control connection transparent to the developer.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.IsClone
member.summary: Gets a value indicating if this control connection is a clone. This property is used with data streams to determine if the connection should be closed when the stream is closed. Servers typically only allow 1 data connection per control connection. If you try to open multiple data connections this object will be cloned for 2 or more resulting in N new connections to the server.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.Encoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the text encoding being used when talking with the server. The default value is Encoding.ASCII however upon connection, the client checks for UTF8 support and if it's there this property is switched over to Encoding.UTF8. Manually setting this value overrides automatic detection based on the FEAT list; if you change this value it's always used regardless of what the server advertises, if anything.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.Host
member.summary: The server to connect to

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.Port
member.summary: The port to connect to. If this value is set to 0 (Default) the port used will be determined by the type of SSL used or if no SSL is to be used it will automatically connect to port 21.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.Credentials
member.summary: Credentials used for authentication

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.MaximumDereferenceCount
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that controls the maximum depth of recursion that DereferenceLink() will follow symbolic links before giving up. You can also specify the value to be used as one of the overloaded parameters to the DereferenceLink() method. The default value is 20. Specifying -1 here means inifinitly try to resolve a link. This is not recommended for obvious reasons (stack overflow).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.ClientCertificates
member.summary: Client certificates to be used in SSL authentication process

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.DataConnectionType
member.summary: Data connection type, default is AutoPassive which tries a connection with EPSV first and if it fails then tries PASV before giving up. If you know exactly which kind of connection you need you can slightly increase performance by defining a speicific type of passive or active data connection here.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.UngracefullDisconnection
member.summary: Disconnect from the server without sending QUIT. This helps work around IOExceptions caused by buggy connection resets when closing the control connection.

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.ConnectTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds to wait for a connection attempt to succeed before giving up. Default is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.ReadTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time wait in miliseconds for data to be read from the underlying stream. The default value is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.DataConnectionConnectTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds for a data connection to be established before giving up. Default is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.DataConnectionReadTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the length of time in miliseconds the data channel should wait for the server to send data. Default value is 15000 (15 seconds).

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpClient.SocketKeepAlive
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating if SocketOption.KeepAlive should be set on the underlying stream's socket. If the connection is alive, the option is adjusted in real-time. The value is stored and the KeepAlive option is set accordingly upon any new connections. The value set here is also applied to all future data streams. It has no affect on cloned control connections or data connections already in progress. The default value is false.

member.name: T:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType
member.summary: Data connection type

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.AutoPassive
member.summary: This type of data connection attempts to use the EPSV command and if the server does not support EPSV it falls back to the PASV command before giving up unless you are connected via IPv6 in which case the PASV command is not supported.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.PASV
member.summary: Passive data connection. EPSV is a better option if it's supported. Passive connections connect to the IP address dicated by the server which may or may not be accessible by the client for example a server behind a NAT device may give an IP address on its local network that is inaccessible to the client. Please note that IPv6 does not support this type data connection. If you ask for PASV and are connected via IPv6 EPSV will automatically be used in its place.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.PASVEX
member.summary: Same as PASV except the host supplied by the server is ignored and the data conncetion is made to the same address that the control connection is connected to. This is useful in scenarios where the server supplies a private/non-routable network address in the PASV response. It's functionally identical to EPSV except some servers may not implement the EPSV command. Please note that IPv6 does not support this type data connection. If you ask for PASV and are connected via IPv6 EPSV will automatically be used in its place.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.EPSV
member.summary: Extended passive data connection, recommended. Works the same as a PASV connection except the server does not dictate an IP address to connect to, instead the passive connection goes to the same address used in the control connection. This type of data connection supports IPv4 and IPv6.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.AutoActive
member.summary: This type of data connection attempts to use the EPRT command and if the server does not support EPRT it falls back to the PORT command before giving up unless you are connected via IPv6 in which case the PORT command is not supported.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.PORT
member.summary: Active data connection, not recommended unless you have a specific reason for using this type. Creates a listening socket on the client which requires firewall exceptions on the client system as well as client network when connecting to a server outside of the client's network. In addition the IP address of the interface used to connect to the server is the address the server is told to connect to which, if behind a NAT device, may be inaccessible to the server. This type of data connection is not supported by IPv6. If you specify PORT and are connected via IPv6 EPRT will automatically be used instead.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpDataConnectionType.EPRT
member.summary: Extended active data connection, not recommended unless you have a specific reason for using this type. Creates a listening socket on the client which requires firewall exceptions on the client as well as client network when connecting to a server outside of the client's network. The server connects to the IP address it sees the client comming from. This type of data connection supports IPv4 and IPv6.

member.summary: Flags that can dicate how a file listing is performed

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.Modify
member.summary: Load the modify date using MDTM when it could not be parsed from the server listing. This only pertains to servers that do not implement the MLSD command.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.Size
member.summary: Load the file size using the SIZE command when it could not be parsed from the server listing. This only pertains to servers that do not support the MLSD command.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.SizeModify
member.summary: Combines the Modify and Size flags

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.AllFiles
member.summary: Show hidden/dot files. This only pertains to servers that do not support the MLSD command. This option makes use the non standard -a parameter to LIST to tell the server to show hidden files. Since it's a non-standard option it may not always work. MLSD listings have no such option and whether or not a hidden file is shown is at the discretion of the server.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.ForceList
member.summary: Force the use of the NLST command even if MLSD is supported by the server

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.NameList
member.summary: Use the NLST command instead of LIST for a reliable file listing

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.ForceNameList
member.summary: Combines the ForceList and NameList flags

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.DerefLinks
member.summary: Try to dereference symbolic links

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.UseLS
member.summary: Sets the ForceList flag and uses `LS' instead of `LIST' as the command for getting a directory listing. This option overrides ForceNameList and ignores the AllFiles flag.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.Recursive
member.summary: Adds the -r option to the list command. Some servers may not support this feature.

member.name: F:FluentFTP.FtpListOption.NoPath
member.summary: Do not retrieve path when no path is supplied to GetListing(), instead just execute LIST with no path argument.

member.name: T:FluentFTP.FtpHash
member.summary: Represents a computed hash of an object on the FTP server. See the following link for more information: http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bryan-ftpext-hash-02

member.name: M:FluentFTP.FtpHash.Verify(System.String)
member.summary: Computes the hash for the specified file and compares it to the value in this object. CRC hashes are not supported because there is no built-in support in the .net framework and a CRC implementation exceeds the scope of this project. If you attempt to Verify() a CRC hash a NotImplemented() exception will be thrown.
member.param: The file to compute the hash for
member.returns: True if the computed hash matches what's stored in this object.

member.summary: Computes the hash for the specified stream and compares it to the value in this object. CRC hashes are not supported because there is no built-in support in the .net framework and a CRC implementation exceeds the scope of this project. If you attempt to Verify() a CRC hash a NotImplemented() exception will be thrown.
member.param: The stream to compute the hash for

member.name: P:FluentFTP.FtpListItem.Parsers
member.summary: Collection of parsers. Each parser object contains a regex string that uses named groups, i.e., (?<group_name>foobar). The support group names are modify for last write time, size for the size and name for the name of the file system object. Each group name is optional, if they are present then those values are retrieved from a successful match. In addition, each parser contains a Type property which gets set in the FtpListItem object to distinguish between different types of objects.

member.summary: Ftp listing line parser
member.returns: FtpListItem if the line can be parsed, null otherwise
